map_node.indicator_description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.

dataset.how_calculated:
Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning AND are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.

 

To learn more about the HVI calculations, visit the HVI FAQ.

 

Visit www.nyc.gov/health/heat for more information about heat illness and how to prevent it. NYS has its own HVI information.
dataset.discription: American Community Survey (2013-2017 5-yr estimates),New York City Department of Parks and Recreation (2017),U. S. Geological Survey LandSat (2018),United States Census Housing and Vacancy Survey (2017)
